text: Decreased concentration of <extra_id_0> 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> s in peripheral mononuclear cells of patients with X - linked hypophosphatemic rickets : effect of phosphate supplementation .
Abnormal renal tubular phosphate transport is considered to be the primary defect in X - linked hypophosphatemic rickets ( XLH ) .
However , the resistance to vitamin D treatment in XLH can not be explained by hypophosphatemia alone .

Since most of the actions of vitamin D are mediated by its receptors ( <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , abnormalities of <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have been postulated in XLH .
In order to investigate this possibility , we measured the concentration of <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in PHA - activated peripheral mononuclear cells from 10 XLH patients .
Patients without phosphate supplementation showed significantly lower concentration ( 21.7 +/- 5.1 fmol / mg protein , mean +/- SEM ) compared to the normal controls ( 60.7 +/- 4.0 ) .
On the contrary , there was no significant difference between the phosphate-supplemented patients ( 58.3 +/- 2.7 ) and controls .
There was a significant positive correlation between <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> concentration and serum phosphate ( P less than 0.05 ) .
In two patients , <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was increased after daily phosphate supplementation was started .

These results indicate that a decreased concentration of <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> secondary to persistent hypophosphatemia is one of the causes of vitamin D resistance in XLH .
